Only recommended if- You have played halflife one(opposing forces is good to have played too)- If you don't mind an old game with lots of small bugs. you have to be a somewhat retrogamer.- If you really love the halflife franchies.(Maybe nostalgic about the game too)- if you want the complete original halflife game history in your library- If you love Calhoun from the later installmentsIf you cannot say yes to any of these, don't bother, Blue shift isn't that good.But for me is was an enjoyment because halflife is my childhood :)As a halflife fan you can skip it, it doesn't matter tribute that much to the story. :)The killers of this game- The game is old, buggy, just like all of the others. No upgrading what so ever in graphic or anything else, shame on you valve!- Lack new content, after having been playing opposing forces with a great range of new weapons, then this seems like a set back, also they seem to have forgot the X-race O.o which they introduced in opposing forces. - This can be somewhat good or bad, but the game has the same way of narrative(or lack of it) in the game like the others. Some people might be turned off- WAAAYYYYY TOO SHORT... Feels lacking, not like a whole "complete" game.The sunshines of the game- I am pretty sure if you love Calhoun in the later installment, you would like this one :)- Maybe a piece of lovely nostalgia- Somewhat very much like the original halflife, so if you still need more this can maybe satisfy your cravings.I can only highlight that is NOT something for players who have not played halflife original or hate elder games. But in the end it is a allround game, for me it was lacking and I liked opposing forces so much better, but I still had a craving for halflife, so this was good for me. :)

Posted: July 7, 2016
												This game shares the same structure and mechanical flaws that Half-Life has, being effectively the same game.  Where this game is set apart from that game though, is in the construction and flow of the game.  This one, (a much shorter game), flows much better, and other than one or two spots, it forgoes the platform game style that Half-Life has.  Only occassionally do you have to leap, duck and weave across impossible terrain and asinine engineered structures, and by the removal of this completely annoying aspect of the original game, this one has not aged as poorly.... Let's face it, games back then, especially of this genre, grew from those platform styled games, and it's what game developers knew, but it's old hat and it doesn't stack up well.  Thankfully Blue Shift doesn't fall into that old game cliche often.The plot for Blue Shift flows better as well.  Instead of just hunting down an alien to kill it, this is a better defined story arc, requiring working towards a non-violent goal of escape (though not without a good dose of alien and military murder-mayhem along the way).  Interesting, considering in the original you're a scientist and this one you're a security guard.For anyone that is curious about Half-Life, this is probably the game for you, since it's short and IMO, better.  (still be prepared for Crate Smashing II - Return of the Exploding Rubbish, and for clunky and clumsy game controls.3.5/5

												This game ties with the first Half-Life game and Half-Life: Opposing Force. You play as Barney Calhoun on a normal day to work at the Black Mesa Reasearch facility, but crap goes wrong and just like Half-Life 1 and Opposing Force, you have to fight aliens from the planet Xen. The game is good so I'll put that there, and you just fight off aliens and squads of stupid NPC Marines trying to kill you of course. The gameplay is not too bad, but the annoying part of the game is that if you use Windows Vista or 7, you may be prone to more game problems and crashes due to the fact the game was not optimized for newer operating systems. You use Windows 8, well you probably don't because the game probably doesn't work for 8. I recommend you use an older machine with Windows 2000 at the highest because this game is pretty old, even for XP. If you do use a older machine, like a Windows 2000 machine to play it you might want to make sure you meet the system requirements so you are not angered by the fact your 2000 OS machine sucks♥♥♥♥♥ The games final rating in my general opinion is 9/10.Up next in reviews by Dead Kitty: Half-Life: Opposing Force!

content:
Posted: July 19, 2013
												I was first introduced to Half-Life: Blue Shift by a dear friend when I was in school. Regrettably, he then took ill for a large amount of time and after that I never heard of him again, but before that he gave me his retail copy of this game. Even after all this time, whenever I play this game I remember the good old days drinking Pepsi Twist over at his house and playing this game until we beat it. Having been both fans of the original Half-Life back in the days we both enjoyed playing this new episode, impersonating a security guard in the Black Mesa Research Facility.As for the gameplay, it's the same as in Half-Life but with some changes in what is mechanics and weapons. Just some minor tweaks. Some locations are revisited, some moments of Dr. Freeman's voyage through the installation can be witnessed, and there are many new locations never seen before.As an expansion to the original game, this game is a blast and kicks♥♥♥♥♥ I'd take this over many new shooters.I dedicate this review - my 100th review on Steam - to my friend. Wherever you are, know that I'm still playing this game while drinking Pepsi and remembering the good old times.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												My review for Half-Life can be seen here:http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198056186683/recommended/70I like to call this game Half-Life: But S.h.i.t.Whats this? A NEGATIVE Half-Life game review? Best to downvote it and not read it. As long as something has Half-Life in the title it can't POSSIBLY be♥♥♥♥♥♥ No. Boring at best and flat out bad at worst Blue Shift has the honor of being Half-Life's red headed step child (No offense to red headed step children.). Many will assume that because it's related to Half-Life it's good or that because it's a expansion much like Opposing Force which is one of the best expansions ever made. Opposing Force was pretty damn good as far as expansions go so this being the Yang to Opposing Forces Yin is disappointing. The only worthwhile thing to come from this was one of the many Barney's getting the last name Calhoun. It has dull puzzles, and uninteresting story that tells nothing new, glitchy physics for NPC's on elevators which was something that both Half-Life Oh, and it has lengthy sewer levels. "How could something made by Valve be bad?" you say. Opposing Force and But S h i t were made by Gearbox in addition to an often forgotten COOP addon for a PS2 port of Half-Life that was worked on by Gearbox. I don't dislike it because it's by Gearbox as that would be petty but if you are inclined to defend it for the glory of Valve as opposed to based on his own merits than at least you know it wasn't now. Opposing Force is one of the few expansions that was not only great but could stand on it's own. While Opposing Force is non canon dissapointingly all thanks to it's inclusion of aliens called Race X. Meanwhile Blue Shift is canon but that might be because it has no new weapons or aliens. Considering the time and location Shepard arrived at Black Mesa it's not to hard to believe that there may be weapons Gordon didn't find as the HECU related weapons that Shepard would come across weren't very common comapred to the MP5/M4. No new weapons is sort of excusable having played future titles like Half-Life 2: Episode 1 and 2 but considering Opposing Force was probably made by similar people it's ridiculous that they learned nothing and that there was no variety. No Race X? Thats fine. Race X don't fit in with Half-Life's aliens and they and the marines suffered from surprisingly bad AI. In Blue Shift the environments are linear, uninteresting and look really out of place. They are REALLY flat. You have sewers, parking lots, sewers, storage rooms, parking lots, sewers, parking lots and Xen. That's a lot of variety ey? All the puzzles take forever and the peices for them move slow as hell. The combat encounters are also a  bore and primarily take place in these afformentioned parking lots which while outdoors don't seem to be part of the facility thanks to poor artistic cohesion. I don't swear often but I must to get to the point and be brash. You are a security gaurd. In Black Mesa. And luckily you are Barney Calhoun out of all of them. Yeah not much is going to happen this should be pretty grounded. Then again this is Black Mesa. Other then the arbitrary showing Black Mesa go to hell during the resonance cascade whats there to show? How many dull ♥♥♥♥ing puzzles can one gaurd survive? I like puzzles so why is this game so bad at them? Where the ♥♥♥♥ are other friendly NPCs and security gaurds after the resonance cascade? You'll see one get killed by zombies and another thrown in a pit but thats all I can recall. Why doesn't Barney talk? The amount of mutes around here is getting out of control. Not only that but if it's canon why is Barney so quiet? If Barney spoke that would really give it some personality. Also I get Barneys resourceful but without the HEV suit or some protective gear he should look like swiss cheese. The story on offer is just so meaningless and worse yet the gameplay is hampered by the awful design. The fact it's version of Xen managed to be WORSE than Xen in Half-Life is amazing. Not to mention he goes to space with nothing but what you see him wearing on the cover. Who needs a space suit when you can hold your breath right? Stay away and buy Opposing Force or Half-Life if you haven't already!My review for Opposing Force can be seen here:http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198056186683/recommended/50

content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
												Half Life: Blue Shift is an expansion of the first Half Life where we play as a security guard and we relive the Black Mesa incident through his eyes but will you want to play it ? In Half Life: Blue Shift we play as Barney Calhoun who works as a security guard  at Black Mesa. The alien and soldier attack happens and we need to escape. So how is Half Life: Blue Shift ? Well I wish there was a mediocre button cause this game ain't bad, but it isn't good either. Compared to Opposing Force this adds nothing to the original game. No new weapons, horrible level design and incredibly short. This expansion  is really nothing special and it pains me to say that. The gameplay isn't even fun this time as this time it revolves around jumping puzzles and not so much around gun fights. This expansion is also really easy compared to Half Life as there is no threat standing in your way. The game is still fun enough for you to finish it but it is very disappointing. Overall there is not much to say about Half Life: Blue Shift. It's not a bad game but it's not good compared to Opposing Force and Half Life. If you want to finish the entire series than by all means pick it up, but if not than wait for a sale or skip this entirely.  I give Half Life: Blue Shift a 6/10

content:
Posted: April 6, 2014
												"Now I wonder if those boys could've made a bigger mess?"Blue Shift takes the perspective of security guard Barney Calhoun during the Black Mesa Incident. Barney would go on to become a major character in Half-Life 2 and its episodes, and playing as such an awesome character brings a lot of fun to Blue Shift. There are no new weapons or enemies, but Blue Shift manages to dish out more amazing action while giving a fittingly different feel from Half-Life and OP4. Playing as Barney makes the player feel ill-equipped and often lowly, due to the limited arsenal and wonderfully condescending dialogue from scientists who give you crap for no reason whatsoever. It may be short, but Blue Shift hasn't a single dull moment and remains a triumph of expansion packs with its intuitive puzzle design, interesting story, and pulse pounding action sequences.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												Well... I did enjoy it... a lot, actually.  Blue Shift is an expansion taking place from the beginning of HL1 to the chapter Apprehension, where Gordon is captured by HECU forces.  But wait, that was still somewhat early in the game, right?  ...Yeah.  We'll get to that.First, I just want to address the things it really got right.  Blue Shift feels like it should-- a complete expansion to the original.  As a security guard, you start off the game first locked out of the office as Gordon slides by looking at you slightly amused, then stopping at the firing range, and watching the Anomalous Materials experiment get prepared on CCTV's.  There's an extreme attention to detail spanning most of the game, and it feels like Gearbox always kept in mind what was happening on Gordon's side.It also does an excellent job of tying together storylines.  While interactions are rare between the stories of Gordon (HL1), Barney (BS), and Adrian (OF), there are constant references and signs where someone who played the other games will recognize key events.  It's definitely interesting to see HL1's plot rewritten from a simple linear story to a whole universal event, now being explored by three radically different roles.On the side, the actual game is... solid.  The levels are decent, the story is good, and overall it feels like more HL1 minus the benefits of the HEV suit, instead opting for standard body armor.  There just isn't that much different from HL1 once you get past the blue HUD and story.  Thankfully, the levels are a completely new deal and while you'll cross paths with key events, the game still stands on its own without constantly relying on you to connect it to the base game.  It's not the kind of game where not knowing the original storyline leaves you completely clueless-- Barney discovers the HECU's mission on his own, he goes through his own escape and survival, and he meets with other scientists in his escape.Still, the biggest flaw I can point out is its time.  Three hours, total.  I'd like to say I got lost or stuck twice.  This is by no means a long game.  Yet, by the end it does start to feel like it overstays its welcome anyway.  It even follows up a teleporter and alien encounter with a fetch quest for more batteries.  FETCHING!  While the pacing in the beginning is exactly as it should be, I feel like the last stage of the game simply dragged on for far longer than it should have.  Still, while not difficult in any sense of the word, the finale is definitely alright for a small expansion-- rather than a boss battle, you more or less follow your fetch quest with an interactive cutscene, which even foreshadows the "Red Letter Day" in HL2 to an extent.Perhaps the biggest thing I can say against Blue Shift, though, is that it has no multiplayer.  This was criminal.  Absolutely unacceptable.  For shame!So yes, I will recommend it, but rather half-heartedly.  You'll have fun with it, but HL1 and Opposing Force have much more to offer.  They're both more interesting and better executed than Gearbox's second expansion ended up being.  Not to mention, it offers much less in content than HL1, which went on for around 9-15 hours plus multiplayer deathmatch, and Opposing Force, which while also somewhat short featured an overhauled multiplayer with CTF and more weapons.  Play those first, and when you see a good sale or don't have other games you can get for this price, go for it.==UPDATE==As commanderox pointed out, you may experience a gamebreaking bug in the opening chapter that prevents you from equipping your body armor and helmet (which triggers an event).  I didn't run into this personally, but a restart should be enough to fix it.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 20, 2016
												Before I go on I want to say a few things about this game. 1. I know this "game" is old but if it's a game that is bad than it's bad regardless of age. 2.I'm going to compare this alot to the original half life becuase it is more of a expansion pack to half life which tells the story from a different POV. 3.This is my opinion so if you don't like it than don't say Im high or Im gay or you ironically feel bad for me since you as a human being(the most intelegent speicies on the planet) can just ignore critizm.The actual review:      So after I beat half life 1's campain a bunch of times I decided to see what this piece had to offer and I was slightly disapointed. The graphics were ok, I mean They didn't add anything new in terms of graphics but they could do worse. The gameplay didn't seem so bad in fact just like the graphics it seems to be exactly the same as half life 1 (yes I know this is a expansion pack) so whats exactly bad about this game you may ask in your head? well for one the pacing and dificulty curve. The game is way too short and the campain lasted me 2-3 hours(the 5.1 was becuase I played it multiple times) and most of what made it dificult was spawn a bunch of enemies and see if you can kill them all to advance to the next area (refering to when you find the scientist in a train's box car.). At the end you (as Barney not Gordon this time) escape Black mesa with a bunch of scientists in a car around the time black mesa is getting bombed. In short this game wasn't exactly bad so to say but it felt very bland and lacking. I say don't get this one unless your planning on getting 1/3 bundles this game is attached to like a parasite living off of the other games for reconition.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2015
												This review originally written on May 21, 2012 on GameFAQs"The weakest of the Half-Life games, but more Half-Life is always good."This is a standalone expansion of the original Half-Life, and the second and final expansion. I recommend everyone plays this first after Half-Life and before Opposing Force for various reasons I will explain. The ratings and my feelings of this expansion are gauged in relation to the first Half-Life.STORY: 9/10You play as Barney Calhoun, security guard. You are actually the security guard you see banging on the door at the very beginning of Half-Life, pretty cool how it's all linked. You experience the events of the resonance cascade but at different parts of the facility. Your main goal is to escape with the scientists. The story actually isn't bad, but it ends kind of abruptly and feels like there should have been a little more.GRAPHICS: 9/10These are the same graphics as the original Half-Life which is both good and bad. The good part is it all looks the same and this expansion came with an HD pack for all the original Half-Life games. The bad part is that when this game came out in 2001 the graphics were starting to look dated even for the time. This isn't a big deal to me as I enjoy the graphics (with the HD pack).SOUND: 9/10The sound is the same as Half-Life. Not changing the alien sounds is fine, but I would've liked some new voices for the guards and scientists. Although there is a new voice for a certain scientist, that's it.WEAPONS: 8/10The weapon system works the same as Half-Life but you get a fewer selection of weapons to play with and no new ones. This is very disappointing.ENEMIES: 9/10You see a return of nearly all of the enemies from Half-Life, but that's it. There is nothing new which is again disappointing.LEVEL DESIGN: 10/10This is the only part where this game lives up to Half-Life. The level design is very similar and the few puzzles and situations where you must figure out what to do are very fun. And you get to revisit my favorite level!LENGTH AND REPLAYABILITYThis game is extremely short, clocking in at 2 hours, 2 and a half if you play on hard and take your time like I did. Still, it is fun to play as Barney and re-experiencing the levels in a future playthrough is certainly viable.FINAL SCORE: 9/10The game is good and well made, but rushed and without any real new content. You should play this before Opposing Force because if you play it after you will be disappointed expecting this to at least be on the level of content of Opposing Force. If you liked Half-Life, this is still a must play.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2012
												Most people say that this is simply more of the same from the first Half Life. I can't say the same, since every 5 minutes has a new game breaking bug. Sometimes it just crashes outright when loading a new area, sometimes it's an essential setpiece that never moves even though it should, and a few times, the game killed essential npcs near the beginning for no reason, resulting in a game over. Reloading an earlier save does not fix the problems, reinstalling usually fixes the particular bug that caused the problem  but it introduces even more. It makes me wonder if there was any playtesting of this. Buyers beware

content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
												A nice addition to the Half-Life universe if not alil short. I felt that the full game had a good focus on both story and combat aspects. Then when I got to Opposing Forces it seemed more on the combat side of things with minor story aspects. This game seemed heavy on the story side with minor combat aspects. It was very short, it took me 3 hours, half as long as the previous add-on and 1/6th the length of the full game. Which is a shame because I actually thought it was better than the previous add-on. The ending was fairly anti-climatic as well...Both add-ons are nice expansions to the full game but do not seem to be necessary to understanding the storyline of the Half-Life universe as of yet... Maybe I'll find out more in Half-Life 2.7/10

content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												I have fond memories of playing Half-life and Opposing Force in my youth, when I read about the new expansion set to come out I was all set to go out and buy it. For one reason or another, I never did. I never thought Id ever revisit the original Half-Life series and never get round to playing Blue-Shift. A bit of free time and a steam sale later, I found myself buying all 3 for £2,74. A bargain!Anyway, I played through Half Life, Opposing Force and then finally Blue Shift, all in the space of about 4/5days. Blue shift is a good game, it is Half-life, but after playing Opposing Force, it just seems like they wern't even trying with this one. It was short, too easy, no new enemies, no new gameplay mechaics, nothing of interest really, it didnt even have a boss/final fight. Im glad in only cost me pence, if I had bought it back in the day I think Id have been really disappointed. I played a lot of Mods on myy original, many of which were better than this official expansion.Play the game, its worth 99p, but dont expect too much.(Anybody know what the zombie game was called and the western, both got released on CD i believe with some magazine.)

												Probably still a must-play for anyone who's fond of the original Half-Life and it's first expansion - Opposing Force.So why don't I recommend this one? First of all, it's very short - took me only 3 hours to beat. Second - enemy placement and spawning is just cheap sometimes. Third - at long ranges enemy AI kind of spazzes out and often completely ignores the player, even if the player shoots them, which is very evident at some of the latest stages in the game. Fourth - there is less enemy and weapon variety than even in the original game, and there is nothing added in the previous expansion pack, Opposing Force.But ultimately it all doesn't matter, since you've probably already got it for dirt cheap as a part of Half-Life or Valve bundle and never gonna play it anyway :)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												If you liked the original Half Life, you will probably like this too. It's essentially the same, aside from showing the origin of Valve (so many valves you need to turn). This time the story is told from a guard's POV. Man, if only the other guards were as useful as Calhoun, the first Half Life would have been so much better!  Just like Freeman, Calhoun started his ordinary day at his job, until the incident happened. Being that Calhoun was a guard and experienced shooter, Blue Shift is more believeable than the original Half Life where a scientist becomes Rambo. Gameplay and visuals are the same since it's using the same engine. Unlike Half Life, it wasn't too heavy on the platforming, but that's probably because the game is really short. While I wasn't trying to break Half LIfe, I never encountered any problems with enemy AI. In Blue Shift, enemy AI was really terrible at times. At one point where you're locked in a truck with the scientist, they kept throwing grenades at the locked door and killed themselves. Another time I flanked them and they just froze and didn't register me at all after shooting them. Guess it isn't as polished as Half Life.NPCs are once again a chore. When I was escorting the scientist to the lab, he kept stopping and complaining that he's tired. The first time he did that was back in the truck. He didn't even leave the truck and he complained about beeing exhausted. Overall, the game was too short to stand out too much, and most of the gameplay was too similar to Half Life. It was still fun playing it and a nice touch, getting to play as one of the guards. From what I hear, this event gets completely ignored in Half Life 2, but can't complain about that, as nothing much happened story wise in this expansion. 6/10

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												I would only reommend this game to someone whose played the Half-life or any other Half-life game before.  From the same friend that introduced me to the Half-life series, I also received knowledge of the splinter games to Half-life and the impression that this game would be about Barney. Wait... Calhoun is Barney? So, I wasn't lied to. Then why didn't any body refer to him as Barney. Where we suppose to know Barney as Calhoun? Regardless, Half-life: Blue Shift made me want to take back on quesioning whether Half-life was too long. Half-life: Blue Shift's brevity and instatenous action brought  an increase satisfaction for Gordon Freeman storyline. I suspect that the game was used to experiment with new mechanics for future games, relative to the release to this game. I admit a certain number of standstill problem solving took a large amount of my time. Fortunately, I didn't need any guides or cheat to figure them out, but that didn't change the very awkwardness of the resolutions. From the spand of 4 hours that it took to finish the game on normal, you can tell that a large portion of the consistented of more tactical problem solving versus rat-in-the-maze problem solving. I cannot argue since I enjoyed the process of "How do I take care of these guys? Well, I seem to be safe in this corner and can shotgun any who pop through that doorway... Wait, they have grenades right now, don't they. Crap, speak of the DEVIL!"Although I cannot think of a way to resolve this, I found the ending dissatisfying and unfulfilling. If not for the credits soon after, I would have thought I still had a chapter or two to still go, but without any closure for the game it ended. I also didn't care for the thrid wheel feel to the game. As Barney, You get to do so much, and carry the story to lead into the Half-life 2 saga. Yes, You see G-man, but much like Gordan Freeman, G-man remains behind the seams.My overall thought is that I would not recommend this game. I cannot think of a reason to tell some "yeah go get this game it has this, and that and so expands on what you would have known about the Half-life series." The game is not a bad game, but I cannot see myself telling someone that the game's worth their time.Overall, I'd rate this 5/10.

												A nice addition to the Half-Life universe if not alil short. I felt that the full game had a good focus on both story and combat aspects. It was very short, it took me 3 hours, half as long as the previous add-on and 1/6th the length of the full game. Which is a shame because I actually thought it was better than the previous add-on. The ending was fairly anti-climatic as well...Both add-ons are nice expansions to the full game but do not seem to be necessary to understanding the storyline of the Half-Life universe as of yet... Maybe I'll find out more in Half-Life 2.7/10

												This is an addon, or should I say, a spin off or something, it's basically half life 1 but in perspective of Barney(Gordon's Friend that is more shown in half life 2) This game runs on the same engine as Half Life 1, but a bit more stable. This game is a bit shorter, same good shooter mechanics and great game overall.Cons: -Good story-Great level design-Great pace of the story-Really good characters-Good interactive "minigames" I could sayPros:-When quicksaving in some places like the last minutes of the game, you will instantly crash, repeatedly.-Sometimes a bit too difficult, but the difficulty can be adjusted though.-Sometimes some Xen levels are confusing-Only occasionally difficult to find out the objective.My personal opinion:     Overall it's a must buy to a shooter lover, half life series fan or anyone basically. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2016
												This game is really good, much better than Opposing Force. Gone are the stupid weapons and enemies and back are the really good ones from the original. The first half of the game the quality of the mapping is about the same as Opposing Force’s, but in the second half it does get a lot better. There is also a considerably better flow and story compared to Opposing Force, here there actually is one compared to the no existent one in Opposing Force.There are no reused sections, although some did seem to take a lot of inspiration from Half-Life’s. However there is a heavy use of sections where you need to go a long way around just to open a door, this is done multiple times. Also not all the weapons are used, this is a good thing is some ways since everything in this game was not out of place, but there are still some non-energy\Xen weapons that are not used.The main problem with the game is that is it too short, it really does feel like they made half the game, then ran out of time. This would explain the lake of weapons and also the lack of difficulty increase, there is no end boss and the end point does feel like a mid-point.But this game is really good, if you had to choose between this and Opposing Force, choose this. Opposing Force was not that great, this however is really good, in some ways better than Half-Life.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												If you liked the original Half Life, you will probably like this too. It's essentially the same, aside from showing the origin of Valve (so many valves you need to turn). This time the story is told from a guard's POV. Man, if only the other guards were as useful as Calhoun, the first Half Life would have been so much better!  Just like Freeman, Calhoun started his ordinary day at his job, until the incident happened. Being that Calhoun was a guard and experienced shooter, Blue Shift is more believeable than the original Half Life where a scientist becomes Rambo. Gameplay and visuals are the same since it's using the same engine. Unlike Half Life, it wasn't too heavy on the platforming, but that's probably because the game is really short. While I wasn't trying to break Half LIfe, I never encountered any problems with enemy AI. In Blue Shift, enemy AI was really terrible at times. At one point where you're locked in a truck with the scientist, they kept throwing grenades at the locked door and killed themselves. Another time I flanked them and they just froze and didn't register me at all after shooting them. Guess it isn't as polished as Half Life.NPCs are once again a chore. When I was escorting the scientist to the lab, he kept stopping and complaining that he's tired. The first time he did that was back in the truck. He didn't even leave the truck and he complained about beeing exhausted. Overall, the game was too short to stand out too much, and most of the gameplay was too similar to Half Life. It was still fun playing it and a nice touch, getting to play as one of the guards. From what I hear, this event gets completely ignored in Half Life 2, but can't complain about that, as nothing much happened story wise in this expansion. 6/10

content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												Well this was underwhelming. I'll vote the game down. Why? Because if one buys the Anthology, he won't care about this at all. But if someone checks the individual games, maybe gets a little look into the game, and I hope that can understand this. To be really short: game is too short, quite shallow, less guns, less varied environments - nowhere as good as HL or Opposing Forces.HL Blue Shift currently stands at 90% positive reviews, while HL and Opposing Forces if I remember well has 96% and 95%  positives, and I have to agree with the trend - the game was fine, but not even as good as HL (This is my third, final review of the anthology - in my book Opposing Forces > Half-Life > Blue Shift, simply based amount the fun I had while playing)The game features a really awesome physics based puzzle (barrels in coolant), had a fun part shooting gas cannisters' top to make them shoot at a door, and a barrel-detonator puzzle  which is really questionable in my opinion. Otherwise this game feels like a well-written, longer trailer for Half-Life. Alien contact's majority are headcrabs, there are maybe two Alien Grunts and Masters - the enemy variety could have been better from the gameplay aspect - the lack of stronger enemies really felt like the protagonist is away from the bigger happenings, making him feel like an underdog.The gametime is about 3-4 hours, and the highs of it are the various little physics puzzles,  but other than that this game is everything but memorable.  We have less weapons than in the base game - Glock, Colt, machine gun, shotgun, rocket launcher, granade and satchel charge. (Plus Snarks, based on wiki) It's about the half of the arsenal we had in the base game or in Opposing Forces - this, with the short campaign makes this game nowhere as fun as the other titles were.

number of helpful: 8 of 18 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2012
												Whereas Opposing Force was Half-Life if Gordon never went to Xen, Blue Shift is just a rerun of the first few levels of HL1. There's no new weapons (even less than HL1 for that matter), very few, if any, memorable set pieces, a handful of easy puzzles, lazy enemy encounters, and the whole experience in general just feels like it's going through the motions.It feels as if it was incomplete, not just because it's incredibly short either, but also because there's no real climax throughout the entire campaign! While Opposing Force was shorter than Half-Life, the tension was constantly rising until it was noticeably more difficult than HL1 ever became. Furthermore, OF introduced many new weapons and (somewhat finnicky) mechanics! You'd think if Blue Shift had nothing new to offer, they'd at least grab everything that made the original so great and go out with a bang, but sadly instead it goes out with a whimper.Shame really, the High Definition patch (circa 2000 standards) is nifty, but I can't say I would recommend going back and playing this one.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												This game is a really lazy attempt to cash in on the popularity of Half-Life. The game is disappointingly short, lacks any serious challenge, interesting weapons, or new enemies. The story is also pretty lack luster. You play as Barney, the security guard you see pounding on the door in the intro to Half-Life, who is later used as a side character in Half-Life 2. The G-Man plays no serious role in the game, unlike his direct involvement in the endings of Half-Life, or Opposing Force. The ending (spoiler alert) falls completely flat. Get teleported to a parking lot, then drive away. No enemies, no hurry, no stress, no reward. Huzzah, right? I want to like this game, but I don't. Gearbox and Valve got really lazy. Your money is better spent on Opposing Force, about 10 new guns, about 5 new enemeis, new bosses, a pretty decent story, and an interesting new perspective. Blue Shift offers none of this, and isn't worth your time.

												The 2nd and final expansion to Half Life. Half Life Blue Shift puts you in the role of Barney Calhoun where you must help a group of scientists escape the Black Mesa facility. The only thing that is new is the HD texture pack which upgrades the textures of the NPCs and your weapons. Again as I said in the last two reviews this is highly subjective and it comes down to personal taste.The game lasted 3 hours for me and it's not as good as the original or Opposing Force but I say you should still play it anyway. It's got a nice enclosed story and still has the same combat and puzzles Half Life has to offer. All in all it's pretty fun and deserves a 7/10.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												I am writing this review under the assumption that you are buying this game alone and not in a bundle. Do not do what I am assuming. This game is way less fun and shorter than Half-Life or Opposing Force. That being said, it is not a bad idea to buy the Half-Life 1 Anthology, because that includes Blue Shift and Team Fortress Classic for the combined price of Half-Life and Opposing Force when not in a bundle. If you were looking for a Half-Life experience, but don't want to buy the Half-Life 1 Anthology, then buy Opposing Force because that expansion lasts a lot longer (6 hours to beat Opposing Force, while only 2.5 hours to beat Blue Shift) and has cooler weapons. I would only ever recommend buying Blue Shift alone if you already have both Opposing Force and Half-Life and are interested in learning more about the Half-Life backstory.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2016
												Blue Shift has one of the most horrible single player games ever. I had more fun playing the free single player games in HL mods such as Azure Sheep (=very good) and Case Closed (=super short, though better than BS). DO NOT BUY THIS GAME! Having played tons of free mods and Opposing Force, Blue Shift sucks big time. Opposing Force gives you cool new guns -- buy that instead if you really want to. Blue Shift was clearly phoned in as a project and that's why it sold poorly. The only good thing that BS added to HL was better quality textures, which you will get anyway if you buy any HL product. There is no reason to buy this garbage. It has a promising beginning and a new security guard model, though it is downhill from there. Don't let this game be a downhill of your wallet. All I can remember from this game is that it was frustrating and boring as hell and it ends suddenly as if the budget ran out. It is even worse than Gunman Chronicles, a retail Half-Life game too weak to get on Steam.

number of helpful: 8 of 19 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2012
												Blue Shift an expansion to the Half-Life franchise but as with any expansion to Half-Life it feels a little underwhelming when held up against the multitude of magnificent mods available for free.Blue Shift casts you as the security guard Barney, letting Gorden Freeman have some quiet time until Half-Life 2 is released and sends you on your marry way through alien monstrosities and overzealous government soldiers. It plays much the same as the original, the weapons and enemies remain unchanged and the maps will feel eerily familiar as you battle through the corridors of Black Mesa.The game just doesn't do anything new, it's feels almost like a recycled game, like you did all this before only it was fun the first time around. Thankfully the game is extremely short so your pain won't last long and you can safely uninstall this and go back the playing the various superior mods for Half-Life, both single- and multi-player.Perhaps the only redeeming quality is the high definition models pack that comes bundled with Blue Shift that gives the game a little a extra. However it should be noted that Half-Life can look much prettier than even that, you just have to play maps and mods that weren't made by Valve.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												THe Second official Expansion to Half-Life and in my opinion the better. While it is actually smaller, both in scope and features the scope makes sense. You play as Barney Calhoun, a member of the Blue shift ..i.e the security force of Black mesa. Yup That's you.The events run parallel to to the story of Half Life and Opposing FOrce though Mr. Calhoun has the distinction of the three which you might already be able to guess at.The Good:* Well Done Areas* Short Play Time* High CHallengeYOu'd think SHort Playtime would be a bad thing but honestly it works to the advantage of the game. Much like Portal it's juuus long enough to be fun but not so long that the areas start to drag on or feel padded. The challenge is ramped up due to the simple fact that barney has limited armor... no HEV, PCV charging or energy packs for you... just whatever you can strip off the corpses of your comrades. It adds a layer of tension.The Bad:* Fewer WeaponsThis is about the only con and it makes sense.Barney is conf9ned to the more mundane weaponry.... but again this feels right.All in all a great addition that does better than opposing force at expanding. opposing Force while good suffered from trying too hard .. Blue Shift is confident enought in what it offers that it doesn't need to throw much in.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												I had actually never played this before, so this one was all-new to me. This is the other spin-off game that Gearbox made from the original Half-Life. This time, you play as one of the security guards at Black Mesa: specifically Barney Calhoun, whom you meet and shoot people with in Half-Life 2. So here's his story about how he managed to get out of there alive.The only real new thing is that since Barney wears "body armor" and not "power armor", you get your armor upgrades via scraps on the ground rather than the energy charger cells or those charger stations on the walls. Beyond that, there's little to nothing new here. The number of weapons is the smallest of any Half-Life game, and there are none that are new. You are pretty much exclusively using "conventional" weapons like pistols, shotguns, and grenades.This is also even shorter than Opposing Force. Took me 2.5 hours without ever having played this before. That's... rather sad.Anyway, this one gets a no vote from me. It has even less stuff than the game it's based off of, and doesn't have any cool new elements like Opposing Force did. I guess play it if you are *really* interested in finding out how Barney got out of Black Mesa, but beyond that... this isn't really worth it.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
Half-Life: Blue Shift brings more Half-Life action for Half-Life fans.Pros: Story, GameplayCons: RepetitiveHalf-Life: Blue Shift follows Barney Calhoun's struggle to escape from the invasion at Black Mesa Research.  The story and gameplay remain true to the original release though not quite as long (though not quite as short as suggested by my playtime, which was mostly offline).Although fans may absolutely love it, the second retelling of the events at Black Mesa begins to lose its excitement.  Barney does reappear in Half-Life 2, but playing through this DLC is unnecessary because he shows little personality as the standard mute protagonist.Fans will enjoy Blue Shift but most everyone else will begin to nod off.7/10

content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												When I read all the negative reviews, I thought: "Hey, this can't be this bad. It's a Half-Life game after all."I was so, so wrong.I'll start with the length - 2 hours and 40 minutes of gameplay. Ok, not bad for a expansion pack. Shame that Opposing Force is a lot longer and costs the same amount of money.Enemies jumping out at you are too predictable. They are more of a obstacle than a challenge here.When I enter a new area I think: "Why am I here?" or "What's the point of this?" instead of "Wow, this is really cool."Then there's the difficulty and health management - or rather the lack of it. Here, I run around with 100 hp and 50 armour on my first playthrough and 50%-100% ammo to all guns instead of the usual, average 70% health and no armour and striving to find more ammo. Here, Ammunition is just there for the sake od it. It's not a life-saver like in the original game. Same applies to health & armour stations/kits.The Hazard Course is not new. They literally took the identical thing from Half-Life and replaced the hologram. Where you originally first see a HEV charger, the pedastal with the arrow is still there as if they didn't even bother removing it.The only actually interesting thing is the level design of some stages, especially the Xen chapter, which is really cool, and you get to see new stuff.Oh, I almost forgot. This has  no new content. That's right. No new enemies or weapons here.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												Besides being short and not bringing nothing new to the table, it's still a fun game. You play as Barney Calhoon, a security guard at black mesa. I'm still suprised that Gearbox didn't make the protagnist talk but thats a just a nitpick.  Anyway if you played half life then the story is the same, but you just have a different point of view.  Later on you meet Dr. Rosenburg who helps you and the other scientists escape black mesa via portal.  At first when you escort Rosenburg, it may seem like a pain but when you get to the lab you start to befriend him.  The foes are still the same and yes, Xen is still a puzzle planet. So overall its a nice different point of view in the half life anthology. Although the game is short, you can explore the stages for easter eggs. So bottom line, if your a half life fan or want to get into half life then I recommend this very well done expansion

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												Half-Life: Blue Shift.  I wish there was such a thing as a Blue Shift in the real world of work, seeing as a Blue Shift at Black Mesa only lasts 3 hours.  Now Half-Life and Half-Life: Opposing Force are not known for their lengthly storylines but one would come to expect a little more from an expansion to one of the greatest games of all time.Blue Shift places the player in the shoes of Black Mesa security officer Barney as he attempts to escape the Black Mesa science facility during the events of the original Half-Life; which run in parallel with the Blue Shift storyline.  Unfortunately the very limited script and lack of anything that could be considered an expansion of the original Half-Life experience means you will feel rather unsatisfied by the rather lacklustre ending to what feels like no more than a fan made mod.The only reason I can recommend for playing Blue Shift is to that you are granted an additional 3 hours of Half-Life gameplay, which can only be a good thing.2 subligars out of 5.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2015
												I wrote this review when watching I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry on Afghan steaming service Sandflix.Barney Calhoun and Doctor Rosenberg are friends and Black Mesa employees.  Widower Barney, who still mourns the death of his wife Chell, is having problems changing the beneficiary on his insurance policy from Chell's name to his children's.  He is worried about his children's future if he were to be killed in the line of duty, and is contemplating quitting his job for something less risky, but he also does not want to forfeit his Black Mesa pension as he also see it as a safety net for his children.  Barney saves Rosenberg's life during the Black Mesa incident.  So when Rosenberg tells Barney that he owes him one, Barney takes him up on his offer.  Barney's favor: despite both being heterosexual, that they enter into a domestic partnership, in name and paper only, to provide that much needed protection for Barney's children.  Chronic womanizer Rosenborg reluctantly but eventually agrees.  The one person who knows for a certainty that they are both straight is their boss, G-Man.  Their plan hits a snag when Barney believes that they are being investigated by the pension department for possible fraud, which means that Rosenberg has to move in with him and his kids.  They consult the advice of a vortigaunt who adds an extra layer of complexity to the situation as Rosenberg in particular is attracted to aliens and believes it could be the one and only for him.  The vortigaunt's advice coupled with it wanting Rosenberg to be it's new best friend makes it even harder on him.Much like man with dwarfism, this game is short.  Also remind me of not so good Adam Sandler films.  Very sneeky.

												Half-Life: Blue Shift is the most disappointing thing since Mr. Plinkett's son. A Half-Life mod that I just can't stand. number of helpful: 3 of 12 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
												I know that I'm going to be hated for this but I don't like this game. It's really not worth it. The game tries little to nothing new or interesting. The story is about one of the security guards of Black Mesa, Barney Calhoun. If you've played Half Life 2, you probably remember the opening where a combine soldier takes you to an enclosed room and reveals to Gordon Freeman that he is one of your best friends. Ok, but that raises the question. If Barney is friends with Gordon then how come you only see Gordon Freeman in Blue Shift once or twice?The gameplay is exactly the same as the original Half-Life. The only difference is that you have fewer weapons than you did in Half-Life 1 and they're all typical weapons that you would find in virtually any FPS ever made and no interesting and or exotic weapons at all; assault rifle, shot gun, pistol, revolver, grenade, satchel charge, rocket launcher, and the  crowbar that was in the original Half-Life game. Oh, and let's not forget that you can't use HEV chargers to charge your armor and can make you take less damage, even though they're all over the game.The enemies are the exact same ones as in the original Half-Life. There are no new ones at all. There is a glitch in the game that made me pull every strand of hair out of my scalp. Right before the residence cascade from HL1, you have to enter an elevator with 2 scientists. Right before the residence cascade, the 2 scientists explode and you have to start over from the last checkpoint and you will go through that glitch again and again, until you start the entire game over.Overrall, this game is not one of the worst game ever, it's just not worth buying. I guess the only redeemable part about this game is the HD pack, which improves the textures, character models, and switches some of the weapon designs to the models from the PS2 port.

Posted: June 20, 2014
												Having played the main story for the Half-Life series years ago, I wanted to play the lesser known Half-Life: Blue Shift.  After finishing it, I didn't find it as fun as I thought it would be but that's mostly because of bugs.  Now the bugs may actually be from the original Blue Shift, it may have came along with the steam port, or I'm simply too used to Valve's more recent games, but either way here are my complaints.- Pressing the use key "E" stops the player from moving, and pressing it repeatedly makes your character stutter.  If you miss grabbing an object and try to grab it again, you will stutter.- Pressing the use key on an object and pressing left or right launches the object at a high speed, sometimes dragging you along with it.- Whenever loading a saved game, attack is almost always on auto, so if you have a crowbard you'll keep swinging until you press attack again.  If you saved with your gun as your weapon, you'll autmatically be shooting when loaded.- Loading spots can sometimes be near an enemy, so if you're moving back and forth to shoot the enemy, you'll keep on loading and lagging.- Not necessarily a bug but there are some things that look like you can crouch jump onto but actually can't.When there are obstacles that involve moving objects around, it becomes kind of frustrating.  I guess the only directions you should use is just forwards and backwards when grabbing things.If you can get past over these it's not a bad game, but not that interesting either.  I would recommend if you're interseted in another perspective on the Black Mesa incident.

Posted: July 11, 2014
												I would like to suggest this game to you, but I have to be careful at the same time. Don't get me wrong, I like this game, but I'm a little conflicted. It has everything I love from Half-Life. the difficult puzzles, simple yet eloquent combat, come to think of it that might be the problem. It's too similar, nothing new really at all. If you want a continuation on Half-Life, which is why I purchased this, you won't be exactly disappointed, but not really impressed either. I did like the addition of getting armor from literal armor and the reticule reacting to being over the enemy, but all-in-all it never made me stop and say "Wow, they put a whole lot of effort into designing these new mechanics!". If, like me, you just wanted another run through of Black Mesa, feel free to purchase this, but if you are given the choice, go with Opposing Force.7.5/10+Still manages a nice story if not a little dull at times.+Keeps the good traits from the original.+Neat scenery as usual.+/- The protagonist being treated poorly by the scientists in the beginning of this story seems like it would be cool, but it ends very abruptly. However one could argue the story is him gaining their respect and becoming a hero. -No new weaponry.-Twists on gameplay rather mundane.-Fighting tends to be very far on the lackluster side.-Lack of enemy variety.-Ending is rather abrupt and isn't anywhere near as challenging to get to as the original.

Posted: June 29, 2014
												If you like the original Half Life, you'll also like Blue Shift.  It's a very similar game, with the same type of action and puzzles (and even the same weapons).  Many of the same enemies return as well, both from Xen and Marines.  If you haven't played the original Half Life, I'd recommend starting there instead.  Both have excellent gameplay, but you get more of the story in the original.I'd recommend Opposing Force over Blue Shift, however.  Both are the same price, but Opposing Force is about twice as long, and is also a much more innovative expansion, with interesting new weapons and levels that differ more from the original than Blue Shift's.  Blue Shift itsn't bad by any means, it just doesn't add new content to the series in the way Opposing Force does.

												This is the weakest of the half-life expansions BUT it has a very solid story along with the original. There are no new weapons or enemies. There are some cool puzzles though and the gun-play is still great. I'd get this with the bundle pack as I don't feel it's worth getting by itself.

Posted: July 4, 2014
												Half Life: Blue Shift is simple, short, and to the point. It's not some grandiose adventure that has you killing an alien mastermind, it's not you stopping an unlimited power from destroying mankind, it's just a guy running away from danger with a few allies. The mapping is solid, the combat is challenging, there are even a few secrets here and there, but I believe the best thing about this is that the levels set in Xen are extremely fun. Unlike in the original Half Life where they felt tacked on, or in Opposing Force where they were basically easter eggs. On a  less positive note, this expansion limits you to only nine weapons, but in a way, this is also a plus as it simplifies your equipment. Though, there goes the beegun, the gluon gun, the gauss cannon, etc etc. Another unsavory thing is that armor is rare; since you wear security armor you can only scavenge from fallen guards such as yourself, there's no suit recharging, which can leave you quite vulnerable.Besides one completely ridiculous puzzle (at least for me, that is), it is extremely fun and engaging. But be warned, this is the shortest Half-Life expansion, in fact, it doesn't even have multiplayer, so if you're looking for something a bit longer (or with multiplayer action) I'd recommend Opposing Force.

Posted: September 14, 2014
												I recommend this game, but only to diehard Half-Life fans, and even then, that may be a stretch. You see, Blue Shift is actually quite good, remaining synonymous with Half-Life, as far as core gameplay goes. That's just the thing, however -  in essence, this game is virtually part of Half-Life 1 reskinned with less weapons, less story, no significant substance added to the Half-Life universe, and only 6 hours max of gameplay in total. While worth the money, and technically in no way bad per se, compared to the original Half-Life, this game just falls short.But I'm not here to compare this game to HL1, am I? Nope, I'm here to tell you whether or not you should buy this game. So, I'll say this: if you felt that you couldn't get enough of the first Half-Life, then you won't regret purchasing this, the equivalent of a level pack, for five dollars, to get six more hours of Half-Life. Otherwise, look elsewhere; this game brings nothing new other than the maps.

Posted: July 29, 2013
												Allright, time for a re-review.Blue Shift is the last of the side stories for the original Half-Life and once again it was made by Gearbox with help from Valve. But unlike Opposing Force, Valve decided on the story so we won't get any BS Race-X aliens. Anyway, this Side Story lets you play as Barney Calhoun. (The REAL one.)However, Unlike Gordon and Commander Shepard, G-Man doesn't do a damn thing and You're on your own for this one. So yes, this is the ONLY time in the Half Life series (As of this review) where you work for a happy ending and you GET a happy ending. (Until HL2, that is.)The weapons that you can use are way and i mean WAY fewer than HL or HL:OF BUT, with the console you can access HL's Weapon list.If you wanted to know Blue Shift's Weapons: (Crowbar, 9MM, Revolver, Shotgun, Rawket Lawnchair, Satchel Charge, Hand Grenade and the Snarks.) Not as much as Opposing Force, but let's be honest: We are only going to use the shotgun, aren't we?In all, if you wanted to have a quick stroll and look back through time to Black Mesa without the Slog-Fest of Opposing Force or don't want to go through the un-holy mess that is HL's Xen, I would go for this game.For PC and Sega Dreamcast, It's Half Life: Blue Shift released in June 12, 2001!PS: this game does NOT have the "ACTION PACKED AMURRIKIA SAVES THE DAY BY KILLIN ALURRENS" or the "WHAT HAS SCIENCE DONE?!?!?!?!?" style that the other two games have. You have been warned.

Posted: October 11, 2015
												A couple of years after that whole Opposing Force expansion, Blue Shift came out of nowhere with the prospect of a storyline involving one security guard of Black Mesa out of many, who bust out and help out in the middle of the crazy stuff that was unfolding in the middle of the resonance cascade during Freeman's own story.This is another Gearbox Software expansion pack, but this is where the similarity of opposing force ends.Blue Shift also included a "HIGH DEFINITION PACK" that could've been installed across the board with all the Half-Life products that overall improved the much needed quality of a 1998 game. I'm not sure if steam handle the whole thing it also applied to mods like Sven-Co-Op, which at the time, offered a better graphical quality that wasn't offered anywhere else.

Posted: October 28, 2015
												Half-Life: Blue Shift is essentially a DLC pack for the original Half-Life game.  However, it contains enough content and play-time, that is was launched standalone.Half-Life: Blue Shift puts you not in the shoes of the familiar Gordon Freeman from the original game itself, but instead in the shoes of one of the Black Mesa security guards.  You participate in your own adventure that parallels Freemans in the main game, with a few interwoven connections, but the story is truly unique.  You even have a similar run-in with the infamous G-Man as well.I would recommend this game to anyone who has played the original Half-Life game and is interested in the story of Black Mesa.

Posted: June 3, 2015
												Half-Life: Blue Shift is the second expansion pack for Half-Life. You play as Black Mesa security guard Barney Calhoun and it’s a parallel story with Half-Life but short. It’s not that good and I’ll explain why. If you remember from my previous review, Half-Life: Opposing Force featured a decent amount of new content for Half-Life. Now this game is like the opposite were there is no new weapons, NPCs, or weapons but instead just a new 90 to 120 minute campaign just slapped onto the original Half-Life game. However this game does feature the new HD pack, where it basically takes existing models, weapons, and weapon sounds and replaces them with newer, better looking ones. This addon also can be used with the original Half-Life and expansion Opposing Force but that’s really not a big deal for this review. I also noticed that the HD models have washed out looking textures on them for some reason compared to when using them in other Half-Life games. As for the gameplay and everything, it’s really the exact same game but with recycled textures and new maps for the single-player campaign (no multiplayer included). For 2001 this game was just bland by this point especially with titles like Halo hitting the XBOX back in the day. However if you can pick-up this game cheap on steam then get it because it’s certainly not a bad game but nice to play through Half-Life again with a new campaign.

												Half-Life: Blue Shift is an amazing, linear game that has you shooting at zombies, headcrabs, headcrab-mounted zombies, and more as a Black Mesa security guard that had survived the horrible incident. The story couldn't be any more creative then it was back when this first game out, and it still warms my heart when I play it to this day. The graphics were a big upgrade back then, introducing all-new transparency to Source-Engine games, something thought impossible when game companies produced games. The style it was introduced in was phenominal, just a different path then just rushing the games out as in today's modern game. All of this is why this game DESERVES this final rating:+-+-+-+Score+-+-+-+Originality: 18 / 20Style: 19 / 20Story: 19 / 20Compatibility: 20 / 20Control: 19 / 20Total: 85 / 100 - 5 StarsI extremely recommend that you buy this game!

Posted: December 31, 2014
												I'm gonna be honest, I was confused who Barney was in HL2. He revealed himself and I thought "... who exactly are you? Are you an enemy or not?" Then I remember this game, Blue Shift. I remembered reading about this game and the character it spawned, so I paused HL2 for the moment and purchased Blue Shift. It was... decent to say the least. I think taking a character who didn't have a lick of screen time/potential story and making him the main character of his own spinoff is pretty hilarious. In a good way I might add. This game, however had a few really annoying glitches that almost ruined some aspects of the game for me. Everytime I would load after a death, the gun/weapon I was holding wouldn't stop shooting/attacking. While playing on hard mode, where I need every tiny bit of ammo I can get, made this much worse. Something I really love about this game was seeing Gordon at those random parts, those made the whole thing worth while. All and all, I really only recommend this game to fans of Half Life, if nothing else but to experience Barney's adventure.

Posted: January 9, 2015
												The original half life is my all-time favorite game. When I first played half life 2, I was disapointed because it was so different from the original (though dont get me wrong, still a great game.) That being said, Half Life Blue Shift and Opposing Forces are great games because they take place at the same time as thr original and are that same original style and setting. In Blue Shift you play as the security gaurd Barney Calhoun, working your way through Black Mesa, and fighting against aliens and the marines. You see things that you didn't see as Gordon Freeman, which is exciting. So even though it took place at the same time as Half Life, it is still its own game. It is very short but if you loved half life you have to get this game. I highly recommend it, but I would also point out that Opposing Forces was significantly more fun than Blue Shift.

Posted: February 22, 2016
												Half-Life: Blue Shift is an expansion for the critically acclaimed Half-Life. In blue shift, you play as the security guard Barney Calhoun, who was present is the vanilla Half-Life, and the next games in the series. You see the story through his perspective, though the two games are rather similar. You get the same guns, same enemies same enviroments and similar challenges. In essence, this is basically a two-three hour version of Half-Life. It's definitely reccomended for the hardcore fans, but for anyone else it's hard to sell. You're paying for more Half-Life, and that's what you're getting. Blue Shift is kinda fun, but not neccesary to play in order to fully understand the story of the following games.Tl;dr:If you loved Half:Life and are craving for more gameplay that is very similar, buy it. If you're playing it for more story, progression of the main characters or variety in the set-in-stone Half-Life gameplay, Blue-Shift will dissapoint. AND DO NOT choose this as your first game to play in the Half:Life series! Play the original first, and then make the choice.

Posted: April 23, 2015
												This review does NOT contain any plot spoilers. This was a great game for the Half-Life series.  For those of you who have high expectations from modern shooters, then you would be unsurprisingly dissapointed because of your adjusted standards.  This game was made with the original gold source engine back in the early 2000's in which it is apparent to what the engine can and cannot do.The game.  The game can be beaten in a time span of 2.5 to 3.5 hours and it includes the Hazard Course as a tutorial (recommended for adjusting settings before diving into the game.)  It is not long but it is an official story for Barney Calhoun during the Black Mesa Incident.  The gameplay is the same as Half-Life's gameplay except that there is a body armor mechanic that replaces the HEV suit.  The biggest problem in regards to HL: Blue Shift is the Gold Source engine's AI pathfinding issues.  AI characters (NPC's) will only follow you for a certain distance and have trouble going around corners thus making key NPC's frustrating to work with sometimes.  Also, there is no long-jump module.  Out of the 24 times that I've completed this game on the original disc, there were no notable bugs and/or glitches except for a spinning giblet that clips through the wall.

												If you're already getting this from the Half Life Anthology along with Half Life 1 and Opposing Force, you have little reason to read this but if you own Half Life 1 and Opposing Force but not yet Blue Shift, this is for you. I'm still listing this as a reccomendation, but Blue Shift is obviously the lesser of the three Half Life campaigns. Granted, it's still more Half Life, and it's a new campaign from the perspective of Barney, the security guard from Half Life 2 back when he worked at black mesa, but while it isn't as exciting or adds as many new things as Opposing Force, there is another problem you may not be aware of which is that Blue Shift doesn't seem to have recieved as rigerous patching as Half Life 1 and Opposing Force have, and as a result it's a tad buggier, looks a tad worse and honestly does feel a few versions back. Posted: June 12, 2015
												Definitely worth the $1.37 for 3.3hrs of entertainment, but I think the full price of $5.49 is a bit too much.This add-on felt to be overwhelmengly obsessed with the original Half-Life and plugging HL references all over the place, instead of developing the alternate point of view. The structure is also very similar to HL: you come to work, ZOMFG! accident, aliens, then soldiers, then you're on the alien world, you come back, and mess about with teleports while obviously being had by scientists.I think this add-on completely missed out on developing the alternate view point. It did absolute *nothing* to show you the HL events from a point of view of a security guard. You were just like Freeman, trying to GTFO from Black Mesa!Surely an armed security guard at a secret advanced research facility has some sort of protocol for such events that happened? Even the titles that flash at the start say equipment is first priority, personell is secondary, and personal life is of low priority, yet the only thing you're meant to care in the game is your own life.A great way to spin this add-on would've been to follow just that recipe: first you try to save some equipment but then realize it's a hopeless and stupid thing to do; we have to evacuate people! Whoever you're helping however are gunned right and left by soldiers and at the end, you're forced to abandon your job ethics, abandon your morals, and fight for your own life.After the first 5 minutes of the game, the only thing different from this and original HL is that you can't use H.E.V. chargers. Pathetic. I'm only giving a recommendation for the sake of nostalgy.

Posted: October 2, 2011
												Blue Shift is a good game for any Half-Life fans as addicted to Nintendo series. The game stars Barney Calhoun, the generic security guard. The content is not so new, though it boasted the HD pack while release. The Steam edition has it for owners of the game. Most content is taken straight from the original Half Life, making the graphics kind of dated. Only a few parts have all new content such as certain signs and objects introduced for the game. A new character is in the game, playing the role of a scientist. Enemies and guns are limited, with no super cool weapons that the first or second games had. The gametime is short, clocking in at 4 hours compared to HL's 11 and Op's 6 hours. The levels are nicely designed though they borrow heavily from the Half Life kind of levels with a systematic apparoach to the chapters. While the game has small bursts of ingenuity and fun ideas, it is not so original. That being said, this game is good for fans of Half Life looking for a quick HL game.

Posted: June 3, 2015
												Half-Life: Blue Shift is the second expansion pack for Half-Life. You play as Black Mesa security guard Barney Calhoun and it’s a parallel story with Half-Life but short. It’s not that good and I’ll explain why. If you remember from my previous review, Half-Life: Opposing Force featured a decent amount of new content for Half-Life. Now this game is like the opposite were there is no new weapons, NPCs, or weapons but instead just a new 90 to 120 minute campaign just slapped onto the original Half-Life game. However this game does feature the new HD pack, where it basically takes existing models, weapons, and weapon sounds and replaces them with newer, better looking ones. This addon also can be used with the original Half-Life and expansion Opposing Force but that’s really not a big deal for this review. I also noticed that the HD models have washed out looking textures on them for some reason compared to when using them in other Half-Life games. As for the gameplay and everything, it’s really the exact same game but with recycled textures and new maps for the single-player campaign (no multiplayer included). For 2001 this game was just bland by this point especially with titles like Halo hitting the XBOX back in the day. However if you can pick-up this game cheap on steam then get it because it’s certainly not a bad game but nice to play through Half-Life again with a new campaign.

Posted: April 12, 2015
												If you already played half-life or just didn't have enough money to get it at the time because you spent it all, this is a good alternative. Here, you play as Barney Calhoun, security guard from the Black Mesa incident, as you may of already figured by now. There isn't really any notable change in gameplay that I think I should mention, but one. Since you are a security guard, not a scientest "Grunt"(Refers to the new scientest that they make to all the dirty work so that the others don't have to, A.K.A Gordan Freeman and his HEV suit), you will find that you can not use any of the HEV suit chargers found in the game. Instead, you have to find body armor, vests and helmets, often found by dead security guards lying around the facility. The armor works the same as the HEV suit, however. But, the game is only 3 hours long, as this is just an expansion to the original half-life.

Posted: October 2, 2011
												Blue Shift is a good game for any Half-Life fans as addicted to Nintendo series. The game stars Barney Calhoun, the generic security guard. The content is not so new, though it boasted the HD pack while release. The Steam edition has it for owners of the game. Most content is taken straight from the original Half Life, making the graphics kind of dated. Only a few parts have all new content such as certain signs and objects introduced for the game. A new character is in the game, playing the role of a scientist. Enemies and guns are limited, with no super cool weapons that the first or second games had. The gametime is short, clocking in at 4 hours compared to HL's 11 and Op's 6 hours. The levels are nicely designed though they borrow heavily from the Half Life kind of levels with a systematic apparoach to the chapters. While the game has small bursts of ingenuity and fun ideas, it is not so original. That being said, this game is good for fans of Half Life looking for a quick HL game.

Worth it solely because it's still Half-Life 1 and it's still fun.Tip: disable the HD content, and various visual glitches will disappear. And besides, it's the way it's meant to be played!

Posted: July 4, 2014
												Half Life: Blue Shift is simple, short, and to the point. It's not some grandiose adventure that has you killing an alien mastermind, it's not you stopping an unlimited power from destroying mankind, it's just a guy running away from danger with a few allies. The mapping is solid, the combat is challenging, there are even a few secrets here and there, but I believe the best thing about this is that the levels set in Xen are extremely fun. Unlike in the original Half Life where they felt tacked on, or in Opposing Force where they were basically easter eggs. On a  less positive note, this expansion limits you to only nine weapons, but in a way, this is also a plus as it simplifies your equipment. Though, there goes the beegun, the gluon gun, the gauss cannon, etc etc. Another unsavory thing is that armor is rare; since you wear security armor you can only scavenge from fallen guards such as yourself, there's no suit recharging, which can leave you quite vulnerable.Besides one completely ridiculous puzzle (at least for me, that is), it is extremely fun and engaging. But be warned, this is the shortest Half-Life expansion, in fact, it doesn't even have multiplayer, so if you're looking for something a bit longer (or with multiplayer action) I'd recommend Opposing Force.

Posted: July 5, 2014
												Saying if this game is better or worse than the other 2 Half-Lifes is a difficult task. I played all 3 approximately at the same time, and none differ mechanically in any way. They work the same.So the difference is in setting in length and here it's a good news/bad news situation. Good news is ; the storytelling and setting is significantly improved. Not that there was much higher HF could go in that respect, but you get to interact ever so briefly with NPCs in a way that lends them more personality and interacting with Dr. Rosenberg later on is actually well done. Bad news is, it's much shorter and not nearly as challenging. But since it comes with a bundle and is cheap as chips anyway, I recommend it as an added, well designed HF experience.

Posted: July 11, 2014
												I would like to suggest this game to you, but I have to be careful at the same time. Don't get me wrong, I like this game, but I'm a little conflicted. It has everything I love from Half-Life. the difficult puzzles, simple yet eloquent combat, come to think of it that might be the problem. It's too similar, nothing new really at all. If you want a continuation on Half-Life, which is why I purchased this, you won't be exactly disappointed, but not really impressed either. I did like the addition of getting armor from literal armor and the reticule reacting to being over the enemy, but all-in-all it never made me stop and say "Wow, they put a whole lot of effort into designing these new mechanics!". If, like me, you just wanted another run through of Black Mesa, feel free to purchase this, but if you are given the choice, go with Opposing Force.7.5/10+Still manages a nice story if not a little dull at times.+Keeps the good traits from the original.+Neat scenery as usual.+/- The protagonist being treated poorly by the scientists in the beginning of this story seems like it would be cool, but it ends very abruptly. However one could argue the story is him gaining their respect and becoming a hero. -No new weaponry.-Twists on gameplay rather mundane.-Fighting tends to be very far on the lackluster side.-Lack of enemy variety.-Ending is rather abrupt and isn't anywhere near as challenging to get to as the original.

Posted: June 29, 2014
												If you like the original Half Life, you'll also like Blue Shift.  It's a very similar game, with the same type of action and puzzles (and even the same weapons).  Many of the same enemies return as well, both from Xen and Marines.  If you haven't played the original Half Life, I'd recommend starting there instead.  Both have excellent gameplay, but you get more of the story in the original.I'd recommend Opposing Force over Blue Shift, however.  Both are the same price, but Opposing Force is about twice as long, and is also a much more innovative expansion, with interesting new weapons and levels that differ more from the original than Blue Shift's.  Blue Shift itsn't bad by any means, it just doesn't add new content to the series in the way Opposing Force does.
