Posted: June 20, 2014
												Having played the main story for the Half-Life series years ago, I wanted to play the lesser known Half-Life: Blue Shift.  After finishing it, I didn't find it as fun as I thought it would be but that's mostly because of bugs.  Now the bugs may actually be from the original Blue Shift, it may have came along with the steam port, or I'm simply too used to Valve's more recent games, but either way here are my complaints.- Pressing the use key "E" stops the player from moving, and pressing it repeatedly makes your character stutter.  If you miss grabbing an object and try to grab it again, you will stutter.- Pressing the use key on an object and pressing left or right launches the object at a high speed, sometimes dragging you along with it.- Whenever loading a saved game, attack is almost always on auto, so if you have a crowbard you'll keep swinging until you press attack again.  If you saved with your gun as your weapon, you'll autmatically be shooting when loaded.- Loading spots can sometimes be near an enemy, so if you're moving back and forth to shoot the enemy, you'll keep on loading and lagging.- Not necessarily a bug but there are some things that look like you can crouch jump onto but actually can't.When there are obstacles that involve moving objects around, it becomes kind of frustrating.  I guess the only directions you should use is just forwards and backwards when grabbing things.If you can get past over these it's not a bad game, but not that interesting either.  I would recommend if you're interseted in another perspective on the Black Mesa incident.

Posted: June 15, 2012
												This is a nice little addon campaign if you already enjoyed Half-Life 1. Pretty much, you play the game through the eyes of one of the secrutiy guards (yeah?). It fleshes out some of the backstory of Barney Calhoun and contains more of the classic Half-Life gameplay (environmental hazards, crawling through ducts with headcrabs, etc.). However, it is rather short and doesn't innovate much from the base game...the enimes are the same and some show up rarely (zombies) or not at all (black ops soldiers) and it often seems like a  simple rehash. There are few memorable things.The other addon, Opposing Force, was much better made and adds new content. Also, honestly Calhoun just seems too much of a bit player (the game even seems to reinforce this...the one time you see the G-Man, he ignores him...lol).However, if you are a Half-Life fan this will keep you entertained for at least 8-10 hours (on hard difficutly, probably less on others) and is at least worth picking up on sale. 7/10

Posted: February 22, 2016
												Half-Life: Blue Shift is an expansion for the critically acclaimed Half-Life. In blue shift, you play as the security guard Barney Calhoun, who was present is the vanilla Half-Life, and the next games in the series. You see the story through his perspective, though the two games are rather similar. You get the same guns, same enemies same enviroments and similar challenges. In essence, this is basically a two-three hour version of Half-Life. It's definitely reccomended for the hardcore fans, but for anyone else it's hard to sell. You're paying for more Half-Life, and that's what you're getting. Blue Shift is kinda fun, but not neccesary to play in order to fully understand the story of the following games.Tl;dr:If you loved Half:Life and are craving for more gameplay that is very similar, buy it. If you're playing it for more story, progression of the main characters or variety in the set-in-stone Half-Life gameplay, Blue-Shift will dissapoint. AND DO NOT choose this as your first game to play in the Half:Life series! Play the original first, and then make the choice.

Posted: January 28, 2016
												Half-Life: Blue Shift feels like a bit of a disappointment after the amazing job Gearbox did with Opposing Force, however it is still a fun game and well worth playing if you like the Half-Life games. The main problem with Blue Shift is its length. It only takes about 3 hours to complete which is disappointing considering how Opposing Force was around 8 hours long. It also isn't as unique or original as Opposing Force was.However despite its flaws the experience is still a fun one. Seeing how Barney Calhoun escaped Black Mesa is interesting if you have played Half-Life 2. Gordon Freeman can be spotted throughout the game which ties it quite nicely with the original. There are some really great puzzle sections as well which really require you to think. The gameplay is very good just like in the other Half-Life games.Overall, a great game let down mainly by its short length. Worth playing if you are a fan of the franchise.

Posted: June 20, 2015
												Half-Life: Blue Shift is an amazing, linear game that has you shooting at zombies, headcrabs, headcrab-mounted zombies, and more as a Black Mesa security guard that had survived the horrible incident. The story couldn't be any more creative then it was back when this first game out, and it still warms my heart when I play it to this day. The graphics were a big upgrade back then, introducing all-new transparency to Source-Engine games, something thought impossible when game companies produced games. The style it was introduced in was phenominal, just a different path then just rushing the games out as in today's modern game. All of this is why this game DESERVES this final rating:+-+-+-+Score+-+-+-+Originality: 18 / 20Style: 19 / 20Story: 19 / 20Compatibility: 20 / 20Control: 19 / 20Total: 85 / 100 - 5 StarsI extremely recommend that you buy this game!

Posted: June 26, 2016
												Half-Life: Blue Shift is similar to the episodic expansions for Half-Life 2, but in this case it Blue Shift expands of the world of the first Half-Life. Blue Shift has you play as Barney Calhoun, a security gaurd at Black Mesa who gets caught up in the events of the resonance cascade. The objective is the same as in the Half-Life main game, and that is to escape the horrible mess that you are entangled in. The graphics of the game are dated, but are not hard to look at, in fact I would say they give the game a charm to it. The game plays identically to the original Half-Life with no real new gameplay changes; same weapons, and same enemies. There are however a few new textures and characters that are part of the overarching Half-Life story. Blue Shift is an overall great experience that is a must have if you are trying to learn everything about the Half-Life universe.

Posted: July 2, 2016
												Half-Life: Blue Shift is the shortest of the two expansions for Half-Life that provides the back story of Barney Calhoun as he fights to escape Black Mesa with other science personnel.  Players may recall Barney's role in Half-Life 2 and in the case of Blue Shift, it felt nice to view the events of Half-Life through a different lense, just as in Oposing Force.  That being said, the game is indeed short and does not really introduce anything new in terms of weapons or gameplay compared to Half-Life.  The only major gameplay difference is that Barney cannot use the H.E.V. charging stations and instead must collect armor vests and helmets (actually a nice throwback to older shooters).  You'll go back to Xen for a short mission but most of the time you will be working your way through Black Mesa resuing scientists.  There are a few nods to other games in the Half-Life timeline too scattered throughout Barney's journey.  For the price and length of the game, I'd recommend getting this on a sale if you enjoyed Half-Life and want more lore.

Posted: June 26, 2016
												If you liked the original Half-Life (and how could you not?) then you will most likely also enjoy this expansion pack. It is the second Half-Life expansion, following Opposing Force, and while not bringing any new innovations it is very well executed. It is significantly shorter (~4h of playtime) than the original but well paced.

This is not watched, but the faces of the characters look like as realistic. Unfortunately this Supplement the short of all that upsetting. Even more upset that the boss is at the end of the game, and indeed they are not. The ending was very easy when compared with OF. But still have to go, if you want to know more who is this Barney. Because many started playing HL is the second part of the game and asked the questions: "Who is this ?","From where is he ?". Beer 7 out of 10.(Русский)Бесстрашный коп !Не самое лучшее, но и не самое худшее дополнение. Сюжет рассказывает нам про интересного персонажа Барни, которому нужно держать контроль в Чёрной Мезе и служить закону. Главная цель сбежать с Чёрной Мезы, но и не только вам одному, но и профессорам которым вы будете помогать что бы свалить всем вместе с этого страшного места. Еще больше всего расстроило то что босса нет в конце игры, да и вообще их нет. Концовка получилась очень легкой если сравнить с OF. Posted: December 28, 2015
												Half-Life: Blue Shift is an expansion that was to be exclusive to the cancelled Dreamcast port of the original Half-Life. That game was cancelled, but the game lives on, with HD textures, and a third narrative to the Black Mesa Incident. This time, you are everyones favorite security officer and beer-ower, Barney Calhoun. While the weapons are the same, with a few left out, you do get another oppertunity to gun down hordes of Xen aliens and marine soldiers. It's a cheap game, so you should pick it up if you crave Half-Life, or it goes on sale. Seriously, I got it for $1.24 in a sale, and it was worth it.EDIT: Forgot to mention a couple things. One, the game is a lot more puzzle based than the others. Two, the game is much shorter than the others, with no real end boss either.

Posted: January 28, 2016
												Half-Life: Blue Shift feels like a bit of a disappointment after the amazing job Gearbox did with Opposing Force, however it is still a fun game and well worth playing if you like the Half-Life games. The main problem with Blue Shift is its length. It only takes about 3 hours to complete which is disappointing considering how Opposing Force was around 8 hours long. It also isn't as unique or original as Opposing Force was.However despite its flaws the experience is still a fun one. Seeing how Barney Calhoun escaped Black Mesa is interesting if you have played Half-Life 2. Gordon Freeman can be spotted throughout the game which ties it quite nicely with the original. There are some really great puzzle sections as well which really require you to think. The gameplay is very good just like in the other Half-Life games.Overall, a great game let down mainly by its short length. Worth playing if you are a fan of the franchise.

												When I first played this game, I had never played the original Half Life. I know, that's weird, but this was my introduction. Everything feels a bit to floaty for my liking. The graphics, in my opinion, still hold up today. The textures aren't overly deatailed and nothing looks amazing. But the graphics are just fine.It's said that this game is too short, with an average overall playthrough lasting 2 hours. But if you're me, the game lasts for six hours. Overall, Half Life Blue Shift is a perfectly fun game, especially if you play it not thinking about how it holds up to the original Half Life.

Posted: November 7, 2013
												Oh well. After Playing through Blue Shift on Hard difficulty I have to say that I can understand the criticism this game got. But after all it was a really good ... little campaign. I think the points of criticism (no new Weapons, no Endboss, no new Enemies etc.) are valid considering the original Half Life and its quality. But surprisingly enough these points seemed very fitting to me. I mean after all we aren't the Hero of the story. We are nothing special at all. We are just a security officer that tries to get the hell out of the catastrophy he got into. Why should he use some super powered Weapons ? He uses what he can find. Why should he beat a giant Alien or Endboss ? He is simply trying to get away, not trying to save the world (like Rosenberg pointed out during the Elevator Scene). Other than that I have to say that I found the atmosphere to be really amazing. I felt like a confused lonely surviver trying to stay alive running for his life. All these dark coridors and the environment crumbling away. Electricity shooting out of walls and stuff like that. The biggest personal point of criticism for me is that it only took me 4 hours to complete the campaign on the hardest difficulty. Ultimately, if you enjoy the Half Life Universe I can recommend you to play it. Its short, its atmospheric, its intense.

Posted: December 20, 2016
												A decent edition to the Half-Life franchise, this game doesn't add a whole lot new to Half-Life as a whole, but it's still a decent play, so here are some pros and cons. Just like Opposing Force, any pros and cons Half-Life has, Blue Shift has.Pros-No special armor/shielding system, you aren't a scientist or soldier, just a squishy security guard. This mixes things up a bit if you've played Half-Life and Opposing Force.-Storyline running parallel to Gordon Freeman and John Shepard's.Cons-Shorter storyline than both Half-Life and Opposing Force.-No new enemies or weapons that I can think of.So obviously more of a redo of Half-Life with little variation for those of you who've played it . I'd still recommend it because it is enjoyable and gives you the feeling of playing Half-Life without having to repeat Half-Life. That being said, given its smaller, less varied nature, it's understandable if you don't get this game.

Posted: July 2, 2016
												Half-Life: Blue Shift is the shortest of the two expansions for Half-Life that provides the back story of Barney Calhoun as he fights to escape Black Mesa with other science personnel.  Players may recall Barney's role in Half-Life 2 and in the case of Blue Shift, it felt nice to view the events of Half-Life through a different lense, just as in Oposing Force.  That being said, the game is indeed short and does not really introduce anything new in terms of weapons or gameplay compared to Half-Life.  The only major gameplay difference is that Barney cannot use the H.E.V. charging stations and instead must collect armor vests and helmets (actually a nice throwback to older shooters).  You'll go back to Xen for a short mission but most of the time you will be working your way through Black Mesa resuing scientists.  There are a few nods to other games in the Half-Life timeline too scattered throughout Barney's journey.  For the price and length of the game, I'd recommend getting this on a sale if you enjoyed Half-Life and want more lore.

Posted: June 28, 2016
												The second “interquel” to Half-Life is lived through the eyes of Barney Calhoun, a security officer at Black Mesa, that is seen by Gordon Freeman at the very beginning of the game. This game also takes place at the same time as Half-Life, but starts before the incident and is chronologically placed prior to Opposing Force. Barney’s journey through Black Mesa isn’t an easy one, but surely it is a short one, as Blue Shift is even shorter than Opposing Force. Also, the game doesn’t add any major improvements over other games in the series, and is thus to be considered just another expansion of the story. A really nice one at that, at it deserves a playthrough for sure, but the story will be over very soon. Unfortunately.

Posted: June 28, 2016
												Half-Life Blue Shift is a fun game. It does have problems though. Compared to Half-Life 1 and Opposing Force, this is the least good out of the three. It didn't introduce any new enemies or guns. It also didn't really have any awesome boss fights like the other two before it. The storyline isn't nearly as in depth or good as HL1 or OF. The game is SIGNIFICANTLY shorter than HL1 and OF. Nothing really new came out of the game. I feel that the makers of the game could've done a way better job. However, since I am a big Half-Life fan, I do think this game is fun to play. There are moments where the combat is intense. I would say it's a nice little game to play and finish in one weekend. It was worth the 99 cents I payed in the summer sale. If you're a Half-Life fan, you at least owe it to yourself and the series to pick up the game and play it.

Posted: July 27, 2016
												Half-Life: Blue Shift is a very short game and can take you a maximum of 3 hours. That's how long it took for me at least, others say that it took them about 2 hours to be the game. It's as short as MGSV: Ground Zeroes, but doesn't mean that I didn't have with this game. On the contrary, I enjoyed it for what it was.GAMEPLAY!The game plays just like Half-Life 1 and Opposing Force (no big surprise, honestly), but instead of the HEV or PCV suit from the other games, you have your security guard helmet and vest as the armor you got. You can't use the Health or Shield regeneration station, instead you must find pick up dropped helmets and vests from dead security guards. It makes sense as in the other games, the security guards never really seem to be wearing any special suits like the HEV or PCV.There is no new weapons in this game, all you have is the standard military weapons from the original game. There is also no new enemies to fight, you got the Vortiguants, Marines, Headcrabs, Barnacles, and Zombies. I pretty sure there were more enemies, but those are only ones I remember.Pretty much, this is like the original game except your a security guard.LORE!As I said, there are no new enemies so, you won't be seeing any new aliens or special black ops here like Opposing Force did. Instead, you will be fighting the traditional enemies from the base game. In terms of story, it answers some questions, such as how Barney got out of Black Mesa and how does the portals work. There not a lot of things here that is new here. VERDICT!Although, I really listed a lot of cons to the game that will turn people off. I'm still going to reccomend this for anyone who wants a little more insight on Black Mesa and the Security Team. It's definitely not a bad game, but it just lacks anything new. Still, I think people will find it pretty enjoyable.

Posted: February 7, 2015
												I'll put it simply. Half-life Blue Shift was visually impressive and had some cool scripting when it came out. Besides that though, it's largely a dissapointment. It's not that the game isn't fun, or doesn't have it's moments-it does- but it doesn't fill the standard that Half-life and HL:OpFor set. Besides the overall game time and plot both being lacking, it also shoots itself in the foot by not including as many weapons or enemies. Only about half the arsenal is included (no energy weapons, missing a couple explosives, and no Xen/Race X weapons). While I don't fault this game for leaving out the Race X creatures, I DO MISS the Xen creatures (and human enemies) that fail to show up. You don't get to fight any mutated zombies (OpFor), Icthysaurs (underwater things), boss enemies, black ops or assassins, and you only fight a handful of grunts and the flying mini-Nihilanth things. The game is still enjoyable, but it's not highly recommendable.  If you're a HL fan or just craving a decent shooter however, perhaps this may appease you. 6/10

Posted: November 7, 2013
												Oh well. After Playing through Blue Shift on Hard difficulty I have to say that I can understand the criticism this game got. But after all it was a really good ... little campaign. I think the points of criticism (no new Weapons, no Endboss, no new Enemies etc.) are valid considering the original Half Life and its quality. But surprisingly enough these points seemed very fitting to me. I mean after all we aren't the Hero of the story. We are nothing special at all. We are just a security officer that tries to get the hell out of the catastrophy he got into. Why should he use some super powered Weapons ? He uses what he can find. Why should he beat a giant Alien or Endboss ? He is simply trying to get away, not trying to save the world (like Rosenberg pointed out during the Elevator Scene). Other than that I have to say that I found the atmosphere to be really amazing. I felt like a confused lonely surviver trying to stay alive running for his life. All these dark coridors and the environment crumbling away. Electricity shooting out of walls and stuff like that. The biggest personal point of criticism for me is that it only took me 4 hours to complete the campaign on the hardest difficulty. Ultimately, if you enjoy the Half Life Universe I can recommend you to play it. Its short, its atmospheric, its intense.

Posted: December 20, 2016
												A decent edition to the Half-Life franchise, this game doesn't add a whole lot new to Half-Life as a whole, but it's still a decent play, so here are some pros and cons. Just like Opposing Force, any pros and cons Half-Life has, Blue Shift has.Pros-No special armor/shielding system, you aren't a scientist or soldier, just a squishy security guard. This mixes things up a bit if you've played Half-Life and Opposing Force.-Storyline running parallel to Gordon Freeman and John Shepard's.Cons-Shorter storyline than both Half-Life and Opposing Force.-No new enemies or weapons that I can think of.So obviously more of a redo of Half-Life with little variation for those of you who've played it . I'd still recommend it because it is enjoyable and gives you the feeling of playing Half-Life without having to repeat Half-Life. That being said, given its smaller, less varied nature, it's understandable if you don't get this game.

Wether you're a scientist in a bright orange ♥♥♥ suit smashing Crowbars into the faces of Alien Monsters. Climbing slowly out of the hell of a hidden government facility. Posted: January 18
												Blue Shift is a very short expansion pack for Half Life 1 for a reason, and it is the fact that, unlike Opposing Force, it doesn't add anything too new to the game. The same weapons present in Half Life 1 are seen here, but the weapons that were in Opposing Force not being in this expansion pack is a mystery to me. I mean, at least the .357 pistol could be here since Otis uses it. Anyhow, it is short because Gearbox knew there was no point in trying to make it as long as Opposing Force since there wasn't much new content aside from yet another view of the Black Mesa incident from a security guard's eyes and a new scientist character that never appeared in any HL game after this one.Still, Blue Shift still feels like how a Half Life game should feel like. The feeling of loneliness is much more present here and I have to say the atmosphere is very immersive, just like in the original Half Life and Opposing Force. If you enjoyed Half Life 1, go ahead and play this one too for some extra 2 or 3 hours of Half Life experience as Barney Calhoun.

Posted: February 1
												No gimmicks, no overbearing mechanic tutorials, just a simple, average, short and sweet first-person shooter action. Salt of the earth, Barney Calhoun must navigate deeper into a crumbling Black Mesa facility to aid the scientists in undoing what they have wrought. Enjoyable for solidly satisfying gameplay and at the right length lest feeling belabored *cough* half-life *cough* Blue Shift is a comfy tag-on that increases the value of the valve and half-life bundles.Purchased with valve collection during winter sale 2016MR. DEPENDABLE AWARD

Posted: November 10, 2016
												This has always been my favourite of the three Half-Life games and I can't really put my finger on exactly why.I think it's the sense of realism. On your way to work, you see the outside of Black Mesa. You see your colleagues eating breakfast and getting their laundry. The door to your working section won't open. You go to a shooting gallery and a room with security cameras. You see the security guards' locker room. All the scientists have different personalities. All the small details in everyday life is here. Not to mention the elevator part. This is my favourite part in the whole series. It's terrifying and at the same time it feels more realistic than most things in the game, because it actually could happen in real life (except the aliens part, of course). What a way to start the game!The High Definition Pack was a nice addition in the original release as well, which deserves high points.The only things that bug me are the short length, the lack of new weapons and an overall grey mood that hangs over the game. It's hard to explain and I might be a minority on this, but the sense of fun in the first two games is lacking a bit. The over reliance on puzzles also makes the game seem more like hard work, rather than a pure fun action game. You really have to work for your survival, which is more realistic, but it's a little overkill here for me.I still love the game for its realism. However, in the end, there are more small problems with it than the first two, and with its short length, they are all the more noticeable. It may not be a great game, but it's still good, and even "just good" Half-Life games are a joy.I'd give it a 6,5/10. If you liked the first two, you should at least give it a chance. At the very least, it offers more variety.

Posted: April 10
												"Half-Life: Blue Shift" is the second expansion pack for the acclaimed "Half-Life". Offering little new content, it is usually considered a lesser expansion pack than "Half-Life: Opposing Force" - and I've gotta say I understand this. There are no new weapons in "Blue Shift", and no new enemies. Still, it is a fun little game (it has a mere 8 chapters) with quite a lot of interesting easter eggs, a Gordon Freeman sighting near the very beginning and some interesting maps. And let's not forget that it is the first game in the Half-Life series to feature consistent interaction with a single non-player character. This character, as you may know, is Dr. Rosenberg. "Blue Shift" might not be the most exciting Half-Life game, but it sure is a fun and interesting experience, perhaps mostly for Half-Life geeks like myself.

Posted: January 10
												Graphics: 8/10 Well, slightly better than before.Gameplay: 7/10 Even though there are some good scenes in this, most of it is either a short story segment where you get your next order, or you fighting against enemies, and than solving a puzzle, only to fight against more enemies.Creativity: 7/10 Aside from some interesting puzzles, there isn't much of it in it.Story: 5/10 Aside from having to many unanswered questions for players who are new to Half-Life, there is a main goal (to escape), consisting of many side goals, in a continuos row, even though it's always obvious what happens, and that's it.Difficulty: 4/10 Way to easy, and a real dissappointment.Length: 6/10 Typical Add-On.Final Thoughts: 7/10 It's ok, but it really is just a shooter with a lot of action, and some puzzles, but not really what you'd expect from a Half-Life game.
